Posts.Content: greenacres wrote: I have decided to forego asking directly for the excisional biopsy and asking to have a mammographic person at another hospital review my films for a 2nd opinion. Based on that I will then decide where to go from there. I do have my annual with my ob/gyn on 6/2 - so if needed and I still have left breast pain and the "abnormality/lump" is still there, will ask for a biopsy/excise at that time. I'll keep you posted. I just feel more comfortable going about it this way. I called him and he's having the films sent over and they will call me when they're reviewed them or send me the results. Thanks! Sandra from WI - 12/1/09-IDC, 1.4cm w/DCIS/ALH close to margin. Tumor poorly differentiated w/ comedo necrosis. Posts.Content: greenacres wrote: Hi all! Good news I guess .....remember I asked my ob/gyn for a 2nd opinion (reading of my mammogram films from another hospital), instead he recommended I go see a breast surgeon so they can "feel" my breasts and look at the films at the same time to determine what is in there and decide if it needs to be biopsied or not. The lump is still there and still having breast pain. So, that is good news to me - I think this is better than just having another radiologst who doesn't know anything about my history to re-read my films. I'll follow up again after I see the surgeon. Posts.Content: greenacres wrote: Hi everyone. I am dreading my mammo and us tomorrow, gawd it's all I've been thinking about for the last 2 weeks. Please say a prayer for me that it's benign. I have a lump on the upper outer left quadrant of my breast. I am 37 and I had my first mammo in 2005 with a palpable abnormality as well, which revealed "asymmetrical breast parenchyma, heterogeneously dense" in left breast. Benign, Birads 2, normal I guess. But recently, this breast has become painful and aches a lot. It is not cyclic for sure. Wish me luck. Oh, I was talking to my mom and dad and they said my grandma (paternal) had breast cancer (infiltrating ductal carcinoma) and had a mastectomy with no mestastes. Even though it's not immediate family, does this put me at higher risk? Sandra from WI - 12/1/09-IDC, 1.4cm w/DCIS/ALH close to margin. Tumor poorly differentiated w/ comedo necrosis. Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 10:36AM greenacres wrote: I JUST ran across this at work.  They wanted employees to donate blood and I was told NO, not until I was five years out from "end of treatment".  Each person is different though. I had chemo and radiation and they said concern for recurrence and the five year benchmark was a good one to follow.  For you it may be different since you haven't begun treatment yet, I would definately call and ask. On another note, if I was in a life threatening situation and needed blood....I would take blood from someone who went through breast cancer treatment in a heartbeat.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2007 07:21PM greenacres wrote: WOW, Wallycat, that is something else! I wish you the best on 4/17 and hopefully no surprises as well. It's amazing, isn't it, the technology that is out there and so expensive to use - yet each person is so different that we have to try all these different ones (mammo/us/MRI) to find different cancers in all of us. I have not been diagnosed "yet", but in the process of being tested. I too just feel something "different" in my left breast. I have not called my ob for the excisional biopsy yet. I should really do that - since my mammo/us came out perfectly fine except for some calcifications in my left breast and they also noted very dense breasts - there IS something there, the ob/gyn, the u/s tech and I all felt it. Well, GOOD LUCK to you!

Posts.Content: greenacres wrote: Just curious - in my report it says "Findings: The breasts are heterogeneously dense which limits mammographic sensitivity and can obscure a mass. Within the bilateral breasts, no suspicious calcifications, architectural distortion or dominant suspicious mass is seen. Benign calcifications are noted in the left breast. Benign appearing lymph nodes are seen in the bilateral axillary regions. Some asymmetry of breast tissue greater on the left than the right is seen. This was seen on the prior study as well." Is it normal to actually see lymph nodes on mammography films? Thanks. Sandra from WI - 12/1/09-IDC, 1.4cm w/DCIS/ALH close to margin. Tumor poorly differentiated w/ comedo necrosis. Posts.Content: greenacres wrote: I am concerned.  12/15/09 I had a partial mastectomy/lumpectomy in left breast.  Tumor was against chest wall (stage 1, 1.4 cm, her2+++, er-/pr-, Grade 3 IDC, clean nodes (2)).  I am done with chemo, radiation and continue Herception.  I have been doing BSE's since I stopped Radiation fearful my cancer may return.  In the process of this, I discovered that directly underneath my incision is a hard lump.  It is tender and mobile and feels solid. It is very small.  This was NOT there in the past, over the past year anyway.  I have Herceptin next Thursday (the 27th), but was wondering if anyone else had this and it turned out to be nothing/scar tissue?  How many it turned out to be cancer?  Should I wait or call my doc now?  I'm afraid if I call I will seem like I am worrying too much about little things if it turns out to be scar tissue.  Thanks. Sandra from WI - 12/1/09-IDC, 1.4cm w/DCIS/ALH close to margin. Tumor poorly differentiated w/ comedo necrosis. Posts.Content: greenacres wrote: I have a question. I had a full PET scan prior to my surgery (partial mast) last December. I received a copy of the report shortly thereafter. There was no indication of any cancer in my breast (no uptake), in fact, no mention of my breasts at all. It said there was uptake here and there, but nothing of concern (in my sacroiliac joints and my nasopharynx). Why if I had/have cancer in my left breast, a 1.7 cm size tumor, it wouldn't have seen it? I'm just curious. Of course, the biopsy did reveal IDC, 3 nodes, clean, er-/pr- and her2+++. Some DCIS along with IDC and very close the margin some lobular hyperplasia (which scares me too because it sounded like this was left in my breast and they said "Chemo would take care of that". Thanks! Sandra from WI - 12/1/09-IDC, 1.4cm w/DCIS/ALH close to margin. Tumor poorly differentiated w/ comedo necrosis. Stage 1, Grade 3, ER-/PR- Her2++++ Dx 12/1/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 3, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

I am regretting now that I didn't have a BMX.  I wish I was given that option even at Stage one, but Her2+++ and they found ALH when they removed my original tumor they said "close to the cauterized margin", but that scares me wondering if it still there or if it strayed.  Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: ALH what to expect now swimmom01 swimmom01

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2013 11:01AM greenacres wrote: This is what I do!  I go to the hospital to the medical records department (1-2 days after the procedure) and I complete a small piece of paper for release of information that takes about one minute and they run off the information for me and WALA - I do NOT wait for test results anymore and in most cases, I have the results before my Dr. does.  Yes, at some point they may not be good results, but that is a chance I have to take - at least I know. That's what I do and it works for me.  You should ot have to wait that long for test results it's absolutely ridiculous.  GOOD LUCK and I hope and pray they are benign! :)  Sandra

Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 01:46PM - edited May 31, 2012 01:49PM by greenacres Hi ladies, just checkin' in :)  I have my 1.5 year follow-up in two weeks, bilateral breast MRI.  I am getting nervous but know all will be ok.   I had a PET scan three weeks ago due to some all over body pain I was experiencing and that was good, but it showed uptake in my left breast (the cancer one) and said it should be followed-up with a breast MRI so that's what we're doing.  That makes me a bit nervous...  Anyhoo, hope you all have a wonderful summer, June is going to be crazy, crazy for us. I'll post back with my follow-up on my MRI though.  Hugs to all!  Sandra
